verses.text: The word of the LORD came to Jonah son of Amittai, saying:
verses.comment: Note that Jonah is directly called by the LORD, showing God’s initiative in choosing His prophets. Similar divine commissions are seen throughout Scripture, such as Moses (Ex. 3:4) and Isaiah (Isa. 6:8).

verses.text: "Get up, go to the great city of Nineveh, and cry out against it, for their evil has come up before Me."
verses.comment: Nineveh represents the Gentile nations whom God desires to call to repentance. This foreshadows God's plan for salvation to reach all people (cf. Acts 10:34-35).

verses.text: But Jonah rose to flee to Tarshish from the presence of the LORD. He went down to Joppa, found a ship going to Tarshish, paid its fare, and went down into it to go with them to Tarshish, away from the presence of the LORD.
verses.comment: Jonah's attempt to flee from God highlights the futility of resisting God's will (see Ps. 139:7). The downward movement ('went down') often signifies spiritual decline in the Biblical narrative.

verses.text: But the LORD hurled a great wind upon the sea, and there was a mighty storm on the sea, so that the ship threatened to break apart.
verses.comment: This divine intervention foreshadows Christ's authority over the sea (Matt. 8:24-27). God sometimes employs nature to carry out His will.

verses.text: Then the sailors were afraid, and each cried out to his own god. They threw the cargo that was in the ship into the sea to lighten it. But Jonah had gone down into the inner part of the ship and lay down, and was fast asleep.
verses.comment: Jonah’s sleep amidst danger foreshadows Christ sleeping during the storm (Matt. 8:24). The contrast between the pagan sailors’ prayers and Jonah’s indifference is notable.

verses.text: The captain went to him and said, "How can you be sleeping? Get up, call on your God! Maybe your God will notice us, so that we will not perish."
verses.comment: The captain’s exhortation echoes the call for prayer in times of distress. The urgency to pray is paralleled in the Gospels (Mark 4:38).

verses.text: Each man said to his neighbor, "Come, let us cast lots, so we may discover on whose account this disaster has come upon us." So they cast lots, and the lot fell on Jonah.
verses.comment: Casting lots is seen throughout Scripture as a means of discerning God’s will. God’s sovereignty guides the outcome (Prov. 16:33).

verses.text: Then they said to him, "Tell us, please, for whose cause this evil has come upon us. What is your occupation? Where do you come from? What is your country? And from what people are you?"
verses.comment: Their questions reveal concern for responsibility and identity, themes central in the Biblical narrative of vocation and mission.

verses.text: He said to them, "I am a Hebrew, and I fear the LORD, the God of heaven, who made the sea and the dry land."
verses.comment: Jonah aptly confesses monotheism, affirming God as Creator (cf. Gen. 14:19; Ps. 146:6), a declaration echoed throughout the Scriptures.

verses.text: Then the men were exceedingly afraid and said to him, "What is this that you have done?" For they knew he was fleeing from the presence of the LORD, because he had told them.
verses.comment: Sin often brings fear and consequences not only on the sinner but also on others, an image found repeatedly in Scripture.

verses.text: Then they said to him, "What should we do to you, so that the sea may become calm for us?" For the sea was growing more and more tempestuous.
verses.comment: This question shows the sailors’ readiness to obey the prophet in hopes of divine deliverance.

verses.text: He said to them, "Pick me up and throw me into the sea; then the sea will become calm for you. For I know that this great storm is because of me."
verses.comment: Jonah offers himself for the salvation of others—a sign that prefigures Christ’s sacrificial role (John 11:50; Isa. 53:5), pointing to the mystery of substitutionary atonement.

verses.text: Nevertheless, the men rowed hard to bring the ship back to land, but they could not, for the sea grew more tempestuous against them.
verses.comment: Despite their best human efforts, salvation did not come until they submitted to God’s will—a theme central to the Christian faith.

verses.text: Therefore they cried out to the LORD, and said, "We beg You, O LORD, please do not let us perish for this man’s life, and do not charge us with innocent blood; for You, O LORD, have done as it pleased You."
verses.comment: The pagan sailors appeal for mercy from the true God, highlighting the universality of salvation and foreshadowing themes of intercession and atonement.

verses.text: So they picked up Jonah and threw him into the sea, and the sea ceased from its raging.
verses.comment: Deliverance comes after an act of faith—prefiguring baptism and symbolic surrender of self for the sake of others.

verses.text: Then the men feared the LORD exceedingly, and they offered a sacrifice to the LORD and made vows.
verses.comment: True worship follows deliverance; the Gentile sailors’ sacrifice and vows show authentic faith, foreshadowing the inclusion of the nations in God’s salvation.

verses.text: Now the LORD appointed a great fish to swallow Jonah, and Jonah was in the stomach of the fish three days and three nights.
verses.comment: The three days and nights in the fish prefigure Jesus’ death and resurrection (Matt. 12:40). The image also recalls descent into the depths as necessary for salvation—a profound sacramental mystery and prophecy.
